We saw the mini labyrinth on the way down to the shore, where there are huge logs you can sit on to eat and enjoy the view. 

The hike wasn't difficult. I wore converses and was fine. You often have the choice between stairs or gravel trails.
author: Jessica C.

description: Awesome hike with amazing views! Not sure why I've never been to this Bay Area treasure. The views are so breathtaking. I look forward to coming back again soon!
author: Angela D.

description:
This place makes you feel small in the most wonderful way. It's truly a marvel to stand at the edge and lookout onto the Pacific.

There are a few trails you can take, but I've only ever wandered the Coastal Trail. It's handicap accessible until Mile Rock Overlook and bike accessible until Eagles Point steps. It's a really pleasant, leisurely trail, very low-difficulty that allows you to catch amazing views of the ocean and Golden Gate Bridge. I love coming here when the fog is rolling in -- makes for some amazing shots!

The weather is cold and windy even in summer (it's SF!), so bring a jacket, no skirts and enjoy the view.
author: Mane C.

description: Such a beautiful place to walk and take pictures!! We also watched the sunset, and it was wonderful. We had such a great view.
author: NericePhotography L.

description: One of San Francisco's most beautiful places. Bring a picnic and enjoy the peace that can be found out here. One of San Francisco's coastal gems.
author: Michael G.

description: The hike include stairs but it's not that bad. However, when you reach down to the Pacific Ocean, it is so beautiful! I highly recommend going to lands end. There is also a great view of Golden Gate Bridge which makes the hike worth it.
author: Linda C.

description:
Awesome trail. A friend recommended it to me so I took my girlfriend on a short hike. It was more beautiful than I had expected, right in the beginning of the trail there is a magnificent view of the Golden Gate Bridge. It is a great trail for people who like to whip out a DSLR and take some pictures. The only caveat is to bring a jacket. What started out as a romantic hike was slightly ruined by the cold winds that SF is known for.

What I recommend:

1. Where comfortable shoes and lots of clothes to stay warm
2. Camera or a phone with a good Camera
3. Check out the visitor center
4. Check out the labyrinth
author: Andrew W.

description:
I'm a fifth generation San Franciscan.  Life has taken me far, far away from my beloved ancestral city but I still manage a trip back every two years or so.

Land's End is pretty much my favourite place in SF (which happens to be my favourite place in the world), and I always manage a hike here when I'm in town.  I have lovely memories of walking here with my dad as a child where he'd reminisce about the old Playland at the Beach nearby and we'd look at the crumbling remnants of the Sutro baths.  

Land's End is wild, peaceful, and gloriously scenic.   You will see great views of the Golden Gate Bridge from the ocean side, along with crashing waves, and gorgeous old cypress trees, permanently bent from the wind.  An unmissable SF experience.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
This is the place i usually go to for hiking whenever i feel like walking. 

My brother and i decided to get our morning walk here as our walkout. It was a pretty nice warm day with clear sky that we were able to see the Golden Gate Bridge without the clouds covering the bridge when we went this morning.  

Of course we took the main trail where a lot of people go on since it's about 1 miles or longer kind of trail. it can be narrow and have a lot of rocks in some part of the main trails. you can have a good workout if you walk and run round trip. There's many other small trails too if you want to take other route other than the main trails that a lot of people go on.
author: Julie N.

description:
It is one of the beautiful places to sightsee....Many short trails and a breath taking view every step of the way!

The experience of looking out at the vast pacific is an amazing feeling..
author: Deepti R.

description:
Five freaking awesome and excited stars.

If I told you I grew up in San Francisco and never visited Lands End, would you promise not to smack me?

Well, yeah, I did. And I finally visited this past weekend for the first time.

It was AWESOME. From the gorgeous vista of the ocean to the FREE and plentiful parking to the well-marked trails, Lands End was all that, a bag of chips, and a side of churros, too.

If you're visiting the city, I highly recommend this spot for beautiful sightseeing and a nice break from the concrete jungle.

Bonus: Amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge.
author: Audrey J.

description:
Probably one of the most beautiful places I've ever been to. It's a little out of the way, but I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who finds themselves in the SF area. 

The view is fabulous. You get an amazing view of the Pacific Ocean from a high vantage point along a rocky cliff with flowers framing the way. I'd consider it one of SF's gems, and it's wonderful way to escape the city for a while.
author: Diane Y.

description: I loved walking the coastal trail! I did 4 miles from the Sutro baths to the Golden Gate Bridge. It was a cold, windy Nov day but quite a few people were out as well. The views were stunning! I highly recommend walking the trail!
author: Lemon C.

description:
Hands down, one of the best hiking and sightseeing spots in San Francisco.  I'm a sucker for a gorgeous ocean view, but combined with stunning cityscapes of the Golden Gate bridge - this view is hard to beat.

There are tons of benches around if you'd like to bring a picnic and enjoy a lazy weekend afternoon and the trails are incredibly dog friendly; so if you have a furry friend you should definitely bring them along for the journey.
author: Amanda G.

description: Simply beautiful. You get to see the bridge as well as the breath taking ocean view of the bay. It's a wonderful walk/hike and though the park is huge, it's worth the sweat and sunburn. You  must visit this gorgeous piece of landmark.
author: Tina Y.

description:
If a picture's worth 1000 words, I cannot write enough to describe this place. 

Come here and see for yourself!
author: Richard D.

description: This place is outstanding. We hit this place as the last part of our day.  The views are amazing and the trails are great. If you are visiting from out of town you must add this to your list.
author: Tony L.

description: Nice location to view Sutro Baths, Cliff House, Seal Rock, incoming freighters /aircraft carrier. Hiking trail available to see USS San Francisco Memorial or if walk longer to Legion of Honor museum. Also can sit on park benches and eat sandwiches or your take out while view ocean scenes. We take our visiting friend and relatives here as a tourist spot. Tip:  Go early or risk not finding parking in the lot. Tour busses also come here. No charged fees for parking so people park longer for hiking and exploring.
author: Clifford W.

description:
The fact that you can drive and be so close to this look out, or make a hike out of it makes this place extra special. The views are outstanding and it is very clean. 

You can see the Golden Gate Bridge, but also some awesome ocean and rock views as well. Definitely a must see :) and a great place to take guests.
author: Katherine J.

description: Great easy trail hike. If it's clear you get wonderful views of the pacific, Marin headlands, and the Golden Gate Bridge. If it's foggy you feel like you've been transported outside of the city to an enchanted land.
author: Tevy D.

description:
Second time to San Francisco and second visit here. And any time i'm in the area I'll make sure to take a stroll a long the coast hear. It's a beautiful area to hike, walk, or run. For me it's one the best views of the hold gate and at the right time of day you can feel like your completely alone and just loose yourself in the outdoors.  

The length of trail is nice and it's easily doable if have some time. 

For foot wear I recommend sturdy shoes and boots for the those rainy/damp days.
author: Roberto F.

description: Absolutely amazing. My 60 year old mother climbed the stairs today because the view was so beautiful.
author: Tina B.

description: It was better than I expected. The view was just breathtaking. The beach, trees and plants were a perfect balance of greenery and rocky shore. A lot of stairs but well worth it. Bring water and snacks and comfy shoes!!! Its not worth it to show up cute...seriously. I didn't understand why people showed up with heeled boots and work shoes. U won't last longer than the parking lot....lol!
author: Akane T.

description:
I'm clawing the walls right now, trapped indoors with writer's block. 

I want to be here again. Right now. 

Watched the sunset on a clear day at Land's End a week ago. 

The golden light bouncing off a certain red-orange bridge with the waves crashing against the jagged rocks into white, foamy shards in the air. 

It's the stuff of epic landscape art, entering all who stand and watch into a meditative state of mind. 

Suddenly I wasn't worried about money and other worldly troubles. I felt like I was living in the moment and just thinking about how great it was being there, rather than trying to sort out all of the BS that's just constantly rattling around in my cranial meat while life passes in a blink. 

I don't know how useful any of this information's going to be, but it's a fairly leisurely walk and it's free. 

Go at sunset. 

Live in the moment. 

No regrets.
author: Christine A.

description: I can't believe that as a Bay Area native, I have never been here! What a gem. The views from the Mile Rock Beach area are gorgeous. It is the best part of the Lands End Coastal trail. Just follow the signs and you will get there. The beach is pretty much all rocks with minimum amount of sand. I had on flip flops and was able to walk around just fine but would've loved to have my sneakers for this little hang out since it was rocky. The actual trail was easy. There are steps down to the beach and back up but was not difficult me at all as I enjoy hiking steps!
author: Michelle T.

description:
For views, this place is excellent.  It's a quick 1 mile or maybe 1.5 mile hike along the coast with great views of the golden gate bridge.

The hike itself was really easy, so don't come here if your looking for a workout.  I'd recommend it for tourists and stuff who want to get some great pictures.  The tail has runners going by here and there so you have to watch out for them.

I'd come here if I wanted to some show visiting family some great views, but as for a workout and nature watching, not ideal.  Still great though!
author: Alan W.

description:
I'd give this place TEN stars if I could. And despite me living across the street [LITERALLY. I can see the Cliff House from my living room] this review is completely unbiased. Because even if I lived in a godforsaken place like New York City, the beauty of this corner of San Francisco is undeniable. 

Foggy days make it feel a little more like a nature hike; seriously, it makes me want to bust out my North Face and a granola bar. But on sunny days--zOMG--the kids, dogs, old people, joggers all come out to play and you can just feel the love. *awww*

Three words: FUCKING. LOVE. IT.
author: Valerie C.

description: I have been hiking these trails since my Dad introduced them to me decades ago.  It is much more accessible than it used to be, with well-maintained paths.  Lot's of people use the trails to walk, hike, and take in the views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Marin Headlands, San Francisco's smaller beaches (Baker and China Beaches), the rocky cliffs, and Pt. Lobos Lighthouse.  Traversing west, you will end up at the U.S.S. San Francisco Memorial and the Cliff House.  It is a great hike whether foggy or a blue, sunny day.  Bring your cameras or camcorders.
author: Jeff P.

description:
There really is something to be said about standing on the edge of a continent.

Breathtakingly beautiful, friends. Jaw-dropping, even.

A gorgeous view of the bridge as well as an amazing oceanscape -- I happened to be there during sunset, so bonus points. Serious bonus points.

Nice trails/paths, beautiful plant life, and a sense of absolute serenity. Were I to live in San Fran, I would make the trek to this amazing park often... nevermind that it's out of the way a bit.

Sometimes you just need to stop, breathe, and reflect some. This is one of the more beautiful spots I've had the pleasure to do that in, and I'm glad for it.
author: Rachel F.

description:
Lands End is often characterized as a rocky coastline seascape where photographers and tourists alike share sunrises and sunsets. 

Lands End is a very accessible park with many paved trails, single track dirt trails winding down near the coast and lots of benches to relax and take it all in.

This is a great location for running, hiking and photographing beautiful golden light during sunrise and sunset.

The Lands End Lookout is a Golden Gate Conservatory run Visitor Center that provides information, restrooms and great views of the ocean. You can find the Lands End Visitor Center at GPS 37.779807, -122.511251.

All in all, awesome place for outdoor activities, especially photography.
author: Graham C.

description:
One of my favorite hiking spots in the Bay. Here's the low down:

Pros:
-GORGEOUS views of the water and Golden Gate Bridge (I always bring my camera and snap shots of the bridge if it's not covered in fog)
-it's gives you just enough of a workout without being TOO rigorous 
-lots of shaded areas so it never get's too hot in the direct sun
-easy to find parking lot (I can always find a parking spot)
-did I mention the views are gorgeous?

Cons:
-it can get very, very.....VERY windy
author: Justine M.

description: A little drizzle but otherwise perfect with a picnic lunch with the amazing views.
author: Joe B.

description: Awesome spot. We hiked to the view of the Golden Gate and back to the Cliff House. Great hiking area. Non-strenuous trails.
author: Patrick R.

description: Beautiful! This is the place to take adventurous out-of-towners looking for something off the beaten path.
author: Josephine L.

description:
Before you hit the trail, its always good to stop and just take in the beauty of Lands End. Looking at the ocean and following the water to the GG bridge and bay.

Windy here... but GORGEOUS VIEW!
author: Roger A.

description: I love coming here. The view is so serene and magnificent. It's quite humbling to be face to face with the vast Pacific Ocean. It's a great place to hike and see nature. You also get a beautiful view of the Golden Gate Bridge. On a sunny day, you get a clear view of everything around, from the rocky cliffs to the open ocean. And on an overcast day, the mist cools you off when you take on the trails. Either way, it's perfect. I would recommend this place any day to someone looking for a small adventure in the city.
author: Maria D.

description:
This place is absolutely gorgeous.  We visited in December - skies were clear and it was warm enough to go on a 2-hour hike.  The views along the cliff line were amazing.  Our bulldog had a blast!  He even went through the labyrinth with me!

Park in the large parking lot just above the Cliff House restaurant & take your time - it's worth every minute!
author: Alex B.

description:
A beautiful spot that brings back many great memories.
When I was a teenager, we used to walk over here from my friends' house on Lake St, and then again when they moved to El Camino Del Mar.
I remember 2 lookout points with wooden railings, where we could look out at the water, or look down at people fishing from the shore.
If I could live in SF, I'd want to live in the Sea Cliff area.
author: Ramon V.

description:
One crazily fine day, I hiked from Embarcadero alllllLLLL the way to Land's End.. 'pied' is how I went, oh yeah... (best way to take it all in). 
Sure I got sore when I rode the bus from the Palace of the Legion of Honor back into downtown, but it was an urban hike of a lifetime.. and to go along the trail at this glorious water's edge: priceless... inhale deeply folks... it's the stuff of life, this sea air!!!!!!

Right when one arrives @ Land's End, there is this most adorable landing and small terrace area for very small wedding ceremonies and events, called Eagle's Point... I lagged behind from the pack as I saw what appeared to be a groom waiting for his bride. Alas, I was right! we spoke briefly, I congratulated him and asked him about how he found this magical spot....ahhh, starting life together as one... with their commitment and love as vast as the sea behind them....

But I digress (as is so natural for muddy-headed me)...Land's End is breathtaking, and would perhaps astound and surprise the local who's never bothered to hike this wonderful area of the City. 

I love every single step.....was one amazing afternoon.
author: Jana C.

description:
So, first of all, my daughter told me wear comfy clothes and shoes, jacket or sweater, and of course the San Fran omnipresent scarf (but she didn't tell me where we were going). And, a side note here: I have a teeny, itty-bitty issue with heights. 

Well, I am so happy, thrilled, ecstatic, joyful, rapture....ok, you get the picture. One of the best experiences I've had in San Francisco thus far! With gentle encouragement from my daughter, I followed her lead down every path but, the first path was the hardest (ain't that always the way?) as she easily ambled forward, I hesitantly and slowly followed her as we headed to what looked to me like the edge of the earth...and yet, I did not fall off! Heady stuff for this young minded 62 year old! I'd like to think I am adventurous more and more as I get older.

If you are a lover of hiking, or just meandering up and down natures' pathways, you will love Lands End. Take my word on this...San Francisco IS the place for the foodie but this place is a piece of heaven!
author: Pam S.

description: There is another stunning view at every turn of the trail on this wild and rocky northwestern corner of San Francisco . During your hike you'll see hillsides of cypress and wildflowers, views of old shipwrecks, access to the epic ruins of Sutro Baths, pocket beaches. Awesome place to take pictures as well. Go out and Enjoy!
author: Hasan Y.

description: I LOVE this hike! It's not too strenuous and it has GREAT views of the Golden Gate Bridge!! I would definitely recommend this hike to anyone that wants some nice shots of the bridge and the bay!
author: Amiee H.

description: Great walkable trail that brings closer to the Golden Gate Bridge at each overlook. There's even some light trails that take you Down to the beaches and overlook. Definitely enjoyed my time at lands end. Use the bathrooms first...there are none along the way.
author: Michelle M.

description: OMG. Don't get me started. It's stunning, gorgeous, beautiful, and amazing. You can't find this spot in most American cities right near the Pacific Coast. It has a wonderful hiking, walking, and biking area, but it's small. The area feels so fresh and is well-kept. LOVE IT!
author: Denise C.

description:
Yes! Close to home, beautiful views, straightforward reliable 40 minute there and back leisurely stroll with my dog off leash. It is quite a nice little stretch of peace within city limits. I love it and this is one of my regular get me and my dog moving spots in the city. 

I went there today actually, and as I was walking I realized I have never seen or been bothered by anyone on their cell phone in my slice of nature here! It might just be a fluke and I hope I am not jinxing myself, but in all the times I have been here it seems like all the other people out are actually disconnecting and enjoying nature too! Amazing!

Last side note: Dog owners, hooray GGNRA are dog off leash approved. Although the signage has a little leash on their dog, as of June(?) the law has changed and we win the dog off leash in nature fight! Yay! Hooray! Woohoo! Given that, watch out if you have little doogies because the coyotes here play a tricky game where they send a bitch in heat off to entice your little dog into the den where they EAT THEM! Eep! I've heard some stories from some passers by and seen the horrific fur patches as well as seen coyotes do this to lure my big dog. Luckily my dog was big (90 lbs) and dogly and fought his way free.
author: Kristen E.

description:
nice place from Sutro Baths ruins to great views of Golden Gate Bridge
parking is hard to find though
author: Peter W.

description:
One could die for the beauty here and not feel robbed. It is that gorgeous. 

It was mildly crowded the day we went and still we could find trails to slip away for a brief spot of privacy.

Bring your good camera and your good hiking boots.
author: Joshua B.

description: One of the most beautiful place in San Francisco. Its really windy, but is a Great touristy place. If you are in San Francisco, You Should go there!
author: Danielle S.

description:
If you happen to come into the city for a day spent in the Richmond.  Yes, you came in specifically to go to the Richmond.  And you have just had a meal of Burmese food.  And you have never had Burmese food before.  And you are digging the company.  But you both drank way too much the night before and can't stomach the thought of a drink, but you still want to hang out and you are tired of scanning the aisles at a used book store even though you got to talk about Carrie Fisher and Ibsen, then your best bet is to venture to Land's End.  

There are few sights in SF that are more iconic.  It's where you go to digest your first Burmese experience.  But it is also where you take your 60-year-old mother when she visits.  It is not where you go on a serious hike with a camelpack.  

Also, walk the circular maze that's at the end of the trail.  You won't regret it.  Actually, you may.  It's pretty anti-climatic.

Land's End, however, is not.  It's all sort of climax.

*Did you know that you aren't supposed to use "however" as a lead off?  I learned this recently.  Thanks, Strunk and White.
*Why does the title in this entry have no apostrophe?  Are multiple lands ending and we are merely just acknowledging this fact, but providing no specific land with possession of its end?
author: Jeremy G.

description:
If you are in San Francisco, you must stop at Lands End. The views are absolutely breathtaking, you will not regret it. We came here towards the end of the day/sunset last week when we were in SF and it just blew us away. 

Next time you are in town, definitely make a stop here!
author: Dan N.

description: My favourite Lands End-related hike is to start at the Legion of Honor and walk along the water's edge towards the Pacific Ocean. The shoreline is rocky and windswept and includes numerous hiking direction options, former rail beds, and shore access. And of course there are the views both natural and among fellow travelers. I've come here many a time to clear my head, and to discover that a glorious view, vigorous exercise, and honest introspection are sometimes the best therapy.
author: Eric B.

description:
Refreshing, beautiful, breathtaking.  What can I say that no one hasn't?

Besides the length and variety of the trails, be aware that the parking spots near the trailheads are safest when you're closer to the signage.  I have seen quite a few broken windows and try to avoid parking far away from the entrance areas with luck thus far. 

Another couple of notes--
* Avoid muddy days or wear grippy shoes for those slight/5-8foot long inclines up/down along the trail (sometimes they get muddy or gravelly(?))
* No washrooms unless you count Legion of Honor and the Cliff House viewing center area
* Do bring a light windbreaker or jacket on foggy/cold days -- even those clear days can get chilly as you're trekking along the coast
* The trail deviates in some parts -- some up to the golf course and some down to the beach area, so give yourself time to explore...just stay on path -- really do recommend following the signs because although it looks easy to go off path and down "that way", it's probably not going to end up well unless you're cliffhanger (jk, but really, be safe -- there's quite the drop)
* Folks do bring their dogs on the trails
* People also bike on the trails (don't ask me how they make it up and downhill -- I applaud but certainly couldn't -- so no tips there)
* Lots of photo ops so do bring a camera for those Instagram photos! :D
author: Jennifer Y.

description:
Lands End is a favorite of ours, and we always take out of town guests here for views of the bridge and the Marin headlands. The trails are first rate and fairly easy. The view from the west parking lot is worth taking the time to stop and stretch your legs.

This is the place for a more secluded hike than Golden Gate park, and a place where fewer tourists visit.
author: Monarch B.

description:
Great trails - not too advanced, but still have a good number of steps. Good for clearing your head. Sometimes touristy but better when the weather is foggy or during weekdays. Great view of Marin and the Bridge. Take time to find the unofficial paths, but be careful and don't take the paths that are blocked off. 

Parks like this make me wish I lived in SF...
author: Joyce C.

description: Happen to come across this place right here on Yelp. Took a bus ride from our hotel to the west end of the city to enjoy this place. Found ourselves alone on this gorgeous beach for a while before anybody else had shown up and saw magnificent views of the Golden Gate as well as beach rocks with trails that go through some pretty cool vegetation. I was lucky because my favorite flowers are lilies and we came across a group of wild pink lilies in the middle of tons of green shrub. I didn't see many tourists where we were (which is funny because that's what we were while we were there), and would most definitely say that it's worth the time to travel to for some time away from the chaos in the city.
author: Nathan G.

description: The most beautiful sunset I saw in San Francisco was at Lands End. Absolutely stunning. Explore inside the cave near the water. The black sand will dirty your shoes, but the view at the end is worth it.
author: Amy M.

description: The GPS took us to the wrong place. We also ran out of time so we didn't make it to the "end" where I assume the best views are.  Billy, my dog-brother, enjoyed the hike but I personally expected a little more.
author: Yi Z.

description: Such a beautiful place if you can catch a nice day out here in San Francisco.
author: Jess W.

description: a  must visit when you are in SF!  It is so popular that parking may be a bit difficult (there is a decent-size parking lot and also street parking).  We got lucky that someone was leaving as we got to the parking lot.   It can be a bit cool and windy on this side of the city, so bring a jacket with you.   The trail is fairly easy and relaxing, accompanied by amazing view of the golden gate bridge at many viewpoints.
author: Tiffany H.

description: Gorgeous and breath-taking views of the bay! A great place for a romantic or even a casual date. The Cliffhouse is within vicinity for a romantic date and a walk on the beach. A perfect place when the weather is nice and definitely a great spot to bike around or walk your pooch!
author: Hannah L.

description: Incredible view!!! Take all the trails and explore everything! Amazing view of the Golden Gate and the Pacific all in one place. And great little historical lessons along the way! Absolute perfect!
author: Jenelle G.

description: Awesome views of the Golden Gate Bridge and miles and miles of trails for hiking! Lands End is great especially on a beautiful day. Get out and enjoy nature! =D
author: Sam F.

description: The northwestern section of San Francisco is just spectacular.  It may very well be my favorite part of SF.  Lands Ends is no exception -- the hiking trails -- every single part of this area is beautiful.  A place where you can really get some peace -- during the weekdays especially, this area may even feel a bit deserted.  (Amazing).
author: Mel G.

description:
Pulling up to the Lands End Trail on Thanksgiving with Roxie the Wonder Dog, I remembered how upset I was with local philanthropist Richard Goldman and his grant of 3.6 million to "restore" the trail. The restoration is underway, the beginning of the trail is no longer wild and wooly and overgrown, and word is out - people were everywhere.

We set out on the trail near two families, one little girl worriedly saying I think we're lost, I think we should go back, Auntie, I'm scared, and a boy from another family picked up her riff and said yeah mom, I just want to go back to the car, what are we doing here anyway, I'm bored.

After bonding over the tedium that the adults were forcing on them, Tatonya, Monique and David discovered Roxie, and chased her, running and skipping and screaming delightedly, not catching her for the 2 challenging miles to Sea Cliff. Roxie loves a good game of tag and was happy to oblige. 

Monique's mother had just gotten custody of Tatonya, and was facing the reality of a kid with ADHD...a whip smart child who rocks in a chair so fast it falls over, who can't get to sleep, who never stops. She thought the trail would be a good place for her to run and get it out of her system, and maybe have a good nights sleep. She was hoping that on Monday's doctor visit some low dosage meds could be prescribed to help Tatonya.

I sat down with the kids and Roxie near Sea Cliff, and they were so happy she was still so they could finally pet her. It's hard to find room for three sets of hands on a little dog, so they had to take turns, which led to some good natured quibbling. 

The walk back was beautiful. The kids were getting tired toward the end, and Tatonya slipped her hand into mine for an extra boost, with her Auntie on the other side. David and Monique kept running and chasing each other. At the trailhead, Monique gave me a cup with some shells that she had collected, saying "I want you to have this". 

Lands End Trail is an urban trail like no other in the country. The views of the bay, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands are breathtaking. Last Saturday was a lovely fall San Francisco day. But for our little group, the beauty was completely on the trail itself, with quick friendships formed and a couple of hours to forget our troubles.

For this holiday season, my prayers are: 

For David: May your heart remain open to friendships with girls you meet on the trail.

For Auntie: May you learn how to handle Tatonya, the energy ball of ADHD, and may you be able to continue to provide her with a loving home, and get some rest for yourself.

For Monique: May you remain patient with your cousin, and keep your calm, joyful, loving spirit intact in the middle of the chaos.

For Tatonya: May you find peace and equilibrium, and may your meds be light enough that your sparkle still shines through. (and quit knocking chairs over already!)
author: Gwynnie P.

description: Cool place to explore. The paths are definitely easier and I would suggest this if you're a beginner or just want a nice, calm hike. If you don't know the area, definitely get a map. I ended up going of the trail and kind of got lost, but it was fun nonetheless. There were a lot of mosquitos when you go off the trail, so if you don't want to get bit, stay on the trail or bring bug spray. We wanted to see the ship wrecks and golden gate bridge but it was really foggy. Either way, the sutro baths were cool and the little beach area was nice. I'd come back here again to explore more.
author: Steph U.

description: Yep! This is one of the best places in San Francisco to take a walk. The views are fantastic!
author: Michael S.

description:
Doing something I love to do I spent my Saturday afternoon uprooting invasive radishes on Memorial Slope (below the USS San Francisco Memorial) at Lands End.  I know, I know.  Most people don't visit their favorite parks to disturb the existing ecosystems, but engaging in a bit of habitat restoration is my thing.  I enjoy the volunteer work and since I don't have my own garden to crawl around in I do it through weekend volunteer projects.  After a week of high stress in the workplace who can blame me for going outdoors and taking my frustrations out on unsuspecting plants that grow where they don't belong?  

Lands End Park is part of the huge Golden Gate National Recreation Area.  Located just north of the City's Ocean Beach and Seal Rocks, the park has some well maintained hiking trails and striking views of the ocean, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Marin Headlands.  Even with insects buzzing in my face from the disturbance of their home I sit back on the steep slope and enjoy a breather.  The scene is so serene, and the sound of the waves crashing on rocks below is so relaxing.  If not for the chatter of my fellow volunteers I might actually lean back and take a snooze.  Whether you're into running, hiking, biking or if you're just out for a stroll the trails are wide enough to accommodate everybody.  If exercise isn't your routine take a seat at one of many vista points to absorb the scenery and the sounds of nature.

The habitat restoration project (officially known as the "Lands End Stewardship") takes place every Thursday and Saturday afternoon at 1 PM and members of the public who are interested in volunteering are always welcomed and appreciated.  Monica, one of the GGNRA staff and a project coordinator will reward you with fresh tamales, baked goods, other snacks and water during the break.  Lands End will reward you with its breathtaking nature.  Tools and training are provided.  I know I'll be back.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Hee-hee, I got my friend who "doesn't hike" to come hiking here with me on my most recent trip to this park!  This one is definitely more like a hike than a walk, since there are times where you can imagine that you are not in the city!

So, we found a corresponding walk in Stairway Walks in San Francisco & basically followed it.  Plus, I learned a lot of background info from the book.  There are amazing views of the west side of the Golden Gate Bridge, cliffs, trees, & ocean!

Did you know that if you take the stairs/trail to Mile Rock Beach, then up the path to the right, there's a rock "maze" by Eduardo Aguilera on the ground there?  There was a little kid & his dad wandering in it when we were there.  At some points along the Coastal Trail, you get views of China Beach & Baker Beach.  The El Camino del Mar Trail is a slightly further inland than the Coastal Trail.

The Legion of Honor (which I already reviewed) is located towards the east side of the park.  There's a Holocaust Memorial across from the Legion of Honor.  If you golf, the Lincoln Park Golf Course is located in the park also...the trail borders it on the east side of the park.  The USS San Francisco Naval Memorial is located towards the west side of the park.  Then, the Sutro Baths Ruins are located on the far southwest end of the park.

This is another very popular area, with lots of walkers & joggers.  It was a beautiful sunny day out, & everyone was out enjoying the weather.  In fact, dare I say it, it was hot out the day I was there!  I even got slightly sunburned because I forgot sunscreen.

There's a couple of places to park if you drive, depending on where you want to go...there's a lot by the Sutro Baths Ruins, on Merrie Way (48th & Point Lobos), a lot for the USS San Francisco Naval Memorial, by the Legion of Honor & along the street on that side of the park.
author: Linda T.

description: Enjoy it for the views of the ocean and the old pool. Do take care to wear appropriate footwear. If you plan to walk out into the pool there are some walk paths that are sketchy and can cause you to fall in. The water is murky which can be a great photo shot or a terrible dunk in water you wouldn't dare bathe in. The light can be harsh on your photos so bring a Neutral Density Filter. Do come at Golden Hour. The nearby beach is popular and the trail is a great hike/walk. Parking lot is somewhat of a hassle to get a spot but regular street parking and a couple blocks walk to arrive is not bad.
author: Kelvin M.

description: Lands end was glorious the first time we went (and a nice walk on subsequent trips). We climbed a few of the sediment rocks to our peril. What more is there to say? At the bottom of the cliff there's an interesting beach to walk along, and there's also a maze of stones somewhere.
author: Christophe C.

description:
Lands End is truly amazing.  When I lived in the Richmond I'd go for runs from home through the Sutro Baths side to the Sea Cliff side and back home (it comes out very close to Robin Williams' House--if he's home he puts the flag up!).  I really like the run because there are nice flat parts as well as more challenging parts (e.g., the stairs) and some great views.

One thing I just recently found out about is that on the Sutro Baths side (down to the left at the end of the parking lot, right next to the ocean) there's a very cool tunnel/cave thing.  Check it out!
author: Cassidy P.

description: Lands end is a great hike on the sea cliffs of San Francisco.  Just drive to the Point Lobos Stop or you can drive and park anywhere along El Camino Del Mar.  There is copious amounts of parking at Fort Miley as well.  The trail is follows the coast along the cliffs and provides an amazing view of the Golden Gate Bridge. We went for a nice walk through a nature area, but it seems like a ton of people were exercising or using it for a nice trail run as well.
author: Robert T.

description:
I LOVED, LOVED, LOOOOOOOVED living within blocks of Lands End!

The trails through the park are amazing - they offer breathtaking views of the Golden Gate Bridge, the Pacific Ocean and the entrance to the Bay.  

You will walk on trails hugging the cliff - bringing you to the edge of the city.  Make sure to visit Eagles Point, the Legion of Honor, the Sutro Baths, Mile Rock Beach (watch out for the 100 stairsteps down to the beach), and, if you happen to go during low tide, look for the three sunken ships that peak out of the water just off the coast.

Lands End is a place you can drive to (there's a free parking lot at the entrance to the park) or bus to (the 18 and 38 buses stop right in front).

You will feel totally removed from city life at Lands End!  It's a definite must-do in the city!
author: Christine Z.

description: I had been looking for really cool secret gems in the city & while on vacation in S.F. I decided to put my yelp to the test & this spot was awesome!! It sure is a walk so bring comfy shoes & water if it's warm out. Feels like you'll never get there but it's breathe taking!! So beautiful once you finally get down to the labyrinth & the bottom of the cliffs! You see all the way thru to Golden Gate & far west out the bay! Definitely worth the little hike!!!
author: Alexandra U.

description:
FAVORITE hiking/jogging spot in San Francisco.  Once you're inside the trail, you wouldn't even think you're in the city.  No sounds of cars or honks of buses.  Very well kept trails.  Beautiful views of the Pacific Ocean and the Golden Gate Bridge.  There are several small trails you can take off the main path for exploring.  It never gets old! Love it!

There's parking at the parking lot - above the Sutro Baths ruins (which you can also hike!).
author: Teresa C.

description:
This is such a great hiking/running trail. Just watch out for all tourist getting in 

your way. Great breathtaking views and also a great work out. Just don't come after it

has rained, because it gets really muddy.
author: Amanda C.

description:
This park has a number of dimensions and historical perspectives than any other park that i know of. Also the Golden Gate National Recreation Area is simply an amazingly well done area.

This is one of the few places that I know where you can get a shot of Golden Gate Bridge other than being real close to it. It requires heading down to the old sutro bath ruins then walking around the old and worn down pathway around rocks and on a clear day it is visible and beautiful. All I gotta say is watch your step or you might hurt yourself. 

Great hiking trails and nice scenary as long as it is not foggy, then you get to hear the nice fog horns sort of moaning to the passing ships to get away and be careful of the rocks and stuff. At the same time past a certain point and you need to stop or you need to climb rocks to keep on going. 

The setting sun is magnificent from this vantage point, with it reflecting off of the windows of the cliff house. 

Every time I walk by the USS San Francisco memorial I have to read the inscriptions and of course I am moved by the sacrifices they had make in times of real war.
author: Christopher C.

description: Great hiking.  Highly recommend this park.  Take Uber to parking lot and walk to Golden Gate Bridge.  Or start at GGB and walk other way.  You can walk on beach or stay upper
author: Laurie M.

description:
Absolutely 100% no-doubts-about-it phenomenal.

Plenty of free parking. well maintained trails and freaking unbelievable views at almost every point make this my new gold standard in hiking. The views of the Golden Gate, Marin Headlands + lighthouse, the thundering POOM of the waves hitting the huge rocks, the seals and sea birds, this place had it all.

This is what we are in SF for and this is the reason to be so insanely proud of this area!

Lots of stairs help you gain access to these wonderful sites whilst getting thy behind in shapest most excellent.

Access to the more dangerous parts of this trail has been cut off, so just stay on the major paths and you will be totally fine, although there are some areas that have no railings or safety nets so just use common sense.

Go! Just DO it!
author: Glenn H.

description: Land's End is that rare kind of place that both tourists and the locals can stop and stare in awe. Love it. And so does my dog (although they must be kept on leash.)
author: Priscilla M.

description: Where Lands End begins and Fort Miley starts is unknown. Been coming here for years. Nice place on a nice day.
author: M C.

description: easy hike to bring family/children. awesome views, places to meditate & merge with Mother Nature.  There is both sunny and shady parts, earthly lovely aromas, birds, sea sounds... this is SF! :D
author: Giselle C.

description:
Lands End is a great place for hiking on a nice warm day in San Francisco. There's a few different trails you hike and you can also hike all the way to Legion of Honors while catching a view of the Golden Gate Bridge. If you take the Rock Beach trail (i think thats the name of the trail) you will find yourself a labyrinth! You'll see a flight of stairs going down and VIOLA~ there it is! it's a bit cutty, it took me 2 times to finally locate the place. You can also hike down to the old Sutro Bath house, there is also a mini cave down there that's pretty neat. You can see the waves hit up on the rocks.. 

There are also bikers and runners who share the trail. For hikers this really isn't a workout type of hike, it's more for relaxing and enjoying the view type of hike. 

I still love coming here time to time on a nice day to catch a glimpse of the bay.
author: Jenny G.

description:
Living in a cesspool
surrounding with crackheads
screaming crazy ladies
Wondering SOMA zombies
Run-off of sketchy sixth street
And the air is mostly comprised of weed
And the sidewalks are waxed with fecal matter.
You really begin to forget
The various scents of nature.

Riding through the forest
Off the typical Tenderloin Trail
It is like the tree branch branches out
To you to show off its beautiful fragrance.
I am glad I am a Rockhopper now.
Once and awhile I find it pleasing
To experience the true aroma
Of the original Northern California Coast.
author: Jon-o G.

description: When it's not foggy, the view from here is absolutely stunning. Unfortunately, when it is foggy, you can't see anything. It's worth checking out either way, though.
author: Ryan S.

description: So I just found out about and went to the handmade Labyrinth here. I met some very nice people and they took some great pics (and actually sent them to me!). Going here is a must for any local OR traveler.
author: Jennifer P.

description:
This place is absolutely serene and gorgeous.
A well needed respite from the City.
Beautiful location to view the Golden Gate and if you're lucky see the dolphin swimming in the rocks below.
If you want to see some interesting and gorgeous houses drive around the Sea Cliff neighborhood just adjacent to Lands End.
author: J S.

description: Lands End is the best hike for the entire family with great views of the bay and Marin headlands. It's hard to believe you are in the City. It is Dog friendly but leave the bikes at home. Some drop offs so be careful with the little ones.
author: Mark F.

description: A true gem in beautiful SF. I love it here. Gorgeous views & awesome/challenging trails. Pretty much your outdoor wonderland. It's good for everything, you name it: hiking, biking, walking, or running. Very clean & well maintained. We used to come here all the time. It has changed some over the years. I had the opportunity to run through this park on a GGB Vista run over the weekend and forgot how much I miss this place.
author: Gina N.

description: I am Dora the Explorer when I am with you...you make me feel smart and you make me look beautiful.
author: Salonje R.

description: Doesn't get much better than this when it comes to views. The wind can be pretty brisk but you are in SF so you're always prepared. Great place to come often and stare out into the ocean and all the other sites along the bay.
author: Mike O.

description: Since I've moved up here I've been wanting to check out the cool rock labyrinth I see people taking pictures of. Finally got the chance to check out Land's End a month ago and it's breathtaking. The trail is about 3 miles and not too challenging. I saw a lot of people running it. I opted to walk to take in the nice scenery (I was just lazy). I came on a foggy day so I didn't really get to see the Golden Gate Bridge but I'm sure its gorgeous on a sunny day. Definite must see when visiting SF!
author: Rochelle I.

description:
I was a bit reluctant to write a review about Land's End.  I didn't want everyone else to know about it, but the 130+ reviews leads me to believe that this isn't the secret spot I had thought it was.

The view of the Marin Headlands and Golden Gate while the sun is setting over the Pacific is one of the true joys of living in this city.  The water glistens with orange and white as the sinking sun sets the green hills ablaze in a wash of warm colors.  I try to drive out here a few times a month, just to walk around and take in one of the most beautiful spots in the Bay Area.  With the sun going to sleep and my breath returning to normal, it's a form of stress release that few other activities can recreate.

If you go, try to go at sunset.  If you go at night, bring a flashlight.  And by all means, stay and walk the trails.  Each one offers a different vantage point that lets you soak in the ocean, hills and bridge.  For a cheap date make it a picnic-you'll be crowned a winner.
author: Daniel S.

description: Really cool place to hike, and there is tons to see. The trails are extremely challenging, but they are very fun to maneuver. We bumped into a couple random structures during our hike. My favorite part of our hike was that tunnel that leads to the shore...be careful! Overall, very fun hike and great place to take lots of cool pictures.
author: Sylvester N.

description: I love the Land's End trail.  Must go on a sunny clear day though.  I went today and it was foggy. Couldn't see the GGB at all :( BUT I had beautiful pictures of the coast and trees :)
author: LC B.

description: Scenic views are beautiful. my use for Lands End is to run the stairs and ruins. rock hopping and hiking are what I do best.
author: Matthew A.

description:
It's in the city but feels so far from it. 

Breathtaking views of the Golden Gate bridge, lots of trails to hike, puppies everywhere and a great mix of locals, tourists, sport-fanatics, lovers and older folks. 

Bathrooms are view and far between so ration your water!
author: Mister Chub S.

description:
Wasn't allotted enough time to stomp around in this giant playground, but whatever I saw was good enough to bring me back.  Lands End is perfect, it's great, it's got the most holistically gorgeous view, it's got history, and there are hike paths.  Everything you need for an entire day's adventure, you've got here.
There is tons of parking spaces in Sea Cliff (MY FAVOURITE NEIGHBORHOOD EVER IN THE BAY/MY FUTURE NEIGHBORHOOD) as well as very close to Lands End.  Hop out the car (might want to wear a light jacket or windbreaker), and start walking.  To the east, west, right, left, up and down, there's something to see and something to keep you awed.  
There are old bath houses (or residual structures, at least) to climb on and crawl through.  There are cliffs and slightly steep hills to slide down, run down, hike up.  I've even seen people try to bike these paths.  Great terrain, so why not.
It's just an amazing place.  Definitely devote time for Lands End.  You won't be disappointed.
author: Han P.

description: Simply breathtaking. My best friend and I aren't very outdoorsy people but we decided because the weather was beautiful, we should go for a hike. I went on Yelp of course to look up "hiking trails," and went with Lands End based on the good reviews. The reviews were right! The hike wasn't difficult and the views were amazing. We got a great view of the Golden Gate Bridge and the waves crashing against the rocks was very calming. I'm determined to come back here and have a picnic! I would definitely recommend bringing visitors here if they want a scenic view of the Golden Gate Bridge. I prefer going here over any other "touristy" place in SF.
author: Amy N.

description:
My family loves to camp so we have visited this place a number of times this summer.   

We would usually go up on Friday morning and leave Sunday afternoon.  

We take the boat but they do have boat rentals available.

If you love to fish then this is defiantly the place.  They have quite a few private areas where you can fish and not even be bothered by other fisherman or other campers.  My husband and I pack a lunch and take the kids out on the boat, they love to catch the fish but always throw them back in.  

If you like to hike or run the trails they have plenty of them!   

I would suggest making plans to explore some of the parks around the campground. I wouldn't suggest doing it all at once if you live around the area. Make it fun and go back to do some things that you didn't get to try.  For those of you traveling then I would suggest adding a few days to your trip so that you can see all the attractions.  

For those of you that enjoy a campfire and looking up at the stars while roasting marshmallows it's here!  We do it every evening during our trips and the kids just love it.  Precious moments that you just have to get on camera! 

If you like to play tennis like my son does then you will be happy to know that they have tennis courts available to the public.  They are very well maintained not like some of the ones you see at campgrounds where they cement is all cracked.  

Thumbs up for allowing pets - what would a camping trip be without your whole family!  As long as you clean up after your dog you are good.  

Leave all your worries at home - relax and have fun with the family!  It's a real treat that they have places like this and I hope to go back soon!
author: Sarah D.

description: Not to be missed. Great coffee shop too to get your hike going. Rugged, beautiful, Golden Gate vistas...
author: Elin K.

description: Breathtaking views of the bay on a clear day. A must for anyone visiting that happens to find themselves out at Ocean Beach. It's an easy walk up the hill and well worth the views.
author: Alice S.

description: A real gem. This is what San Francisco is all about. Ocean + Nature + People. I really like and enjoy how the State Park and City of San Francisco redesigned this spectacular of spectacular. Superb! Whether or not you're exploring the Sutro Baths, planting native vegetation with volunteers, or out with that special someone. This place delivers. I can't get enough.
author: Jon H.

description: One of my favorite spots to visit in The City. The views are fantastic, the sea is seemingly never ending, Ocean beach stretches down as far as you can see, and the ruins are a great scenic area to take pictures. This area is typically less crowded, I usually have no trouble finding parking in the free parking lot near the Lands End Visitor's center they're building.
author: Tommy B.

description:
I love love love this place! It's absolutely beautiful. That place makes me very appreciative of living in the Bay. Anyone who lives in this bay who has not visited this place should definitely go.

I advice to be cautious when you go down to the beach. Have someone to go with you in case you trip, you can land on them/scream their names to catch you because their are a lot of rocks/

I discovered this through searching online for nude beaches so hahah
author: Colleen J.

description: Hiking seems to be the new thing, so we hiked at Lands End on a family day.  Only boy, I was in for a ride because after an hour an amateur hiker like me was already breathless.  The paths were not too difficult however you should definitely watch out for runners.  While hiking you can see a beautiful view of the golden gate bridge.  It was breathtaking.  Moreover, we hiked down to the ocean part and it was relaxing and we took pictures.  Due to limited timing, we were unable to hike to the maze! oh what a disappointment but I will definitely come back for the maze,this time I will be more prepared =).
author: Ann L.

description:
One of my dreams came true today. 

Back in my undergraduate years, I used to drive around in my car looking at San Francisco. Even then I was a weekend tourist. One common track was to go from Seacliff to the Cliff House on El Camino del Mar. The clifftop sights were breathtaking. Then, in 1983, a heavy rain storm washed out the road, and it was never repaired. 

Many years I thought of walking past the barricades, to take a look at the washed-out road, to see what had happened, and where. Today, as My Lady and I admired the new parking lot above the Cliff House, she suggested we walk down Land's End Trail. After 25 years I was still curious about the road, and I countered with a request to walk El Camino del Mar. 

Happily, it was on the map, and the National Park Service had built a trail to follow it! With subdued excitement, we walked past the barricades to see the truth of the winter of '83. 

After walking a few hundred yards down the road, the pavement turned into a developed park trail that looked a lot like a bicycle path. Several hundred yards after that, it degenerated to a dirt path, but it was clearly marked and we kept on walking. Here and there, we would catch glimpses of the old blacktop, above us or below us, that let us know we were still following El Camino del Mar. In some places, rather large trees now grew out of the pavement, reminding me of civic ruins I had seen in other countries. 

Under the overhanging cliffs of Lincoln Park we found several ravines, over which the Park Service had built some wooden foot bridges. However, the ravines made it clear that no road would be built here without serious improvements today. Along the way an interpretive sign told us that Adolph Sutro had built the Ferries & Cliff House Railroad along this route, and, yes, one of their biggest problems was that it kept getting washed out. 

The grand finale of the walk was at the Seacliff side, in Lincoln Park.  Near the far barricades, the road dropped about 10 feet, and the pavement slumped straight down the side. As we gazed at the golf greens, the ocean, and the Golden Gate Bridge, I finally resolved the winter storm of '83.
author: David D.

description:
Kinda sorta alot of people, but overall a magnificent place, and I took a dent to my SF credibility when a couple of weekends ago constituted my first visit here. I made up for it by dropping some knowledge on the labyrinth and looking up some knowledge about the Sutro Baths - if my cohorts didn't know either, I guess my credibility isn't that bad. 

There's a bus line pretty much directly there from downtown. Go. Take your sweetie, some shoes that can handle a little bit of mud and a windbreaker. I don't care if it's sunny downtown, you'll thank me for the windbreaker. It's the edge of the biggest ocean on the planet!
author: Ian M.

description:
Land's End feels like Land's End!  It is beautiful and such a luxury to have within San Francisco.  It has great views, romantic spots, and is part of the coastal trail.  While it is a well known tourist spot, I have never been overwhelmed by the crowds.  On multiple occasions, I have enjoyed hiking around.  And while I usually try not to hike alone, I feel like I can get away with it here since there are always some people around.  I enjoyed a nice walk here to do what I do best ... to think ...

And yes, I am appreciating the local parks before the Govern-ator cuts their funding.
author: Anne K.

description:
My father is a man of few words. Sometimes I think that the quiet listener in me comes from him. The crazy [trust me, it's there], spontaneous me? That would be from my mother. 

So one afternoon, I drove out to Land's End with my dad and Cici. We've both lived in this city for 20+ years. It was our first time at Land's End. A quiet, relaxing stroll with the dog, very few actual sentences spoken. I, of course, brought my camera. We soaked in the view along the Coastal Trail, made our trek down to the Labyrinth, and that was our father-daughter bonding time. Hopped back in the car an hour or two later and headed home. 

One day when I'm ready for more than a quiet stroll through Land's End, I'll return with my mother.
author: Tinna H.

description:
Wait, there's a trail?  Where?!

I only visited the park :(  Any who, the park is situated in a secluded neighborhood - one where Borat would definitely say, "ver-ry nice!"  I'm assuming it's one of the nicer neighborhoods of SF 'cause the houses are amazingly huge and gorgeous.

The park is very lovely, with amazing views of the bay and Golden Gate Bridge.  I wanted to go down to the beach area, but my group and I were on a tight schedule so we didn't have time :(  I regret it now!  But the park seriously offers AMAZING views.  If it wasn't for Yelp, I wouldn't have found this gemstone of a park!  I definitely recommend Land's End to anyone, whether they be locals or tourists.
author: Ivy W.

description:
a weekend filled with highs and lows, what better way to wind down and decompress emotionally than with the company of a certified listener / best friend...
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/G8sJ39uxo3sYNMIuyejgTA/l

also, being eased into this mindset of letting go by becoming immersed in simply perfect weather before sunset and the calming sounds of the soothing ocean.
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/1E7YULsO0gWwyoUK-3pZcw/l

with numerous strolls through land's end under my belt i almost felt ashamed for never before exploring the vast amount of side trails that lead to similarly deep introspection on the who, what, when, where, why and how of my life focused on the present, but of course with an eye on the past and future.

as my friends--who have not experienced this SF treasure prior-- and i made way to the famous labyrinth
http://static.px.yelp.com/bphoto/rE3T6Kp-iLvRLZfQDQDT4w/l

we all sat back watched others attempt the maze and reflected why we continue taking steps down a path that leads to confusion, excitement and the like...well thats life i guess.
author: omar b.

description:
DYK meets DYL!

Nothing like a Riptide Red Ale or three at Park Chalet after this hike kicks your out-of-shape ass. 

Go with a cute non-smoking friend for that positive peer pressure. You might enjoy the company and view, forgetting about smoking that cigarette.
author: Kevo M.

description: This is definitely a place to go within the city of San Francisco for a scenic hiking trail..  I usually do the approximately 3 mile walk back and forth from the Fort Miley parkling lot to Eagles Point near El Camino del Mar and 32nd Ave.  On this hike, you can get views of the ocean and (depending on direction of travel) views of the Golden Gate Bridge (at least during a clear day) almost every step of the way.  For those who want a cardiac workout, you'll get one also because of the long series of steps (built from old railroad ties) that you have to go up and down during the middle portion of the hike.
author: H K.

description:
Can you believe that we live in a city where you don't even have to leave city limits to go hiking?  

You want a simple stroll?  You got it.  You want treacherous terrain?  You got it.  You want cliffs and danger?  It's here.  You want stairs?  Sure...but you can also avoid them if you want.  Absolutely stunning.  No need to cross that 'ole bridge.  

Expansive ocean as far as you can see.  I saw three whales here once.
author: Kerry D.

description:
Even on a gorgeous action-packed San Francisco Sunday, there is solace to be had in this place... you (or if you prefer, you and your special someone) can take a quiet, calm stroll in the midst of the cypress trees and find a bit of peace at the end of Geary Blvd. 

Yeah, I know, the words "Peace" and "Geary" don't really sound very harmonic together, do they? 

Amazing views of the Farallones (when it's clear out), the Golden Gate bridge, what is left of the Sutro Baths.... wander thru the trails, bring the kidlets and/or animal companions, and don't forget the camera! 

This place holds a very very special place in my heart. I'll just leave it at that.
author: M'ia K.

description: A great walking/hiking spot.  There are several sets of stairs, ranging from roughly 50 stairs to 230 stairs, which make this a great spot to get some exercise. The surprise comes when you round the first big corner and get a stunning view of the Golden Gate Bridge!
author: Amy J.

description:
A history of favorites:

CHILDHOOD
Food: fresh fruit
Beverage: lemonade
Activity: playing outside

TEENHOOD
Food: Cheetos
Beverage: Coca-Cola
Activity: writing morose poetry

YOUNG ADULTHOOD
Food: macaroni and cheese
Beverage: wine - all of it
Activity: dancing until 1:00am

PRESENT
Food: fresh fruit
Beverage: lemonade
Activity: playing outside

Seems I've come full circle.  Isn't it a little early in the storyline for that?

Lands End is a wonderful place to play.  With many hiking trails, rich history laid out before you on signs that explain everything, and kickass views of the Golden Gate, you just need to remember your windbreaker and gloves.

Make sure to smile at the tourists.  They're cold.  Isn't California supposed to be warm all year round?
author: Bert M.

description:
Right when you enter the trail at the beginning of the Land's End sign you will see a terrace which overlooks the ocean and Golden Gate Bridge.  I was hoofing it behind Gil while he was drinking his Starbuck's coffee with one hand, he pauses, and turns to me pointing to the terrace.

Gil: "Many San Franciscans have taken their lovers, mistresses, partners to ask the all important question....."

Connie: "Marriage?"

G: "No. Will you break up with me?"

C: "Are you serious?"

G: "I know a lot of people who have broken up there and this is where people take them."

C: "Well... I guess if you are going to break someone's heart you might as well do it somewhere beautiful."

Moral of the story:
Whatever you do stay away from that terrace because it is bad luck.   I may be super gullible but Gil seems to know a thing or two about mystical enchanted forests and I would heed his warnings for that terrace brings bad luck to lovers.  

BE WARNED!

Five stars for beautiful vistas and hiking trail.  Minus one star for all the potential heartbreak the terrace may have caused.
author: Connie P.

description:
Probably  the most beautiful hiking in the city. Awe-inspiring views of the ocean, changes in terrain, trails that go down to the beach or up to the Legion of Honor. 

Round out the day with a visit to the Cliff House.
author: N B.

description:
A really different angle to San Francisco. I love being on this side of the GG Bridge. There's something powerful about looking out to sea and knowing there's no other side (at least not for awhile)...

We went on a cloudy day. Minus: a little gloomier. Plus: no naked dudes sunbathing.
author: Keane L.

description: This is truly one of the most beautiful trails/parks in the Bay Area.  It is a great place to have a date and spend time going at the different lookouts together.  The views are spectacular and very romantic.  I love the rock beach and the maze!  If you are there at the right time, you can even see some old shipwrecks off the coast.
author: Katharine A.

description:
Dubya-tee-eff?!? I NEVER knew about this place!

I have lived on the West Side since August of 2006, and thought I had explored my neighborhood VERY well. I've ventured through the Presidio, Golden Gate Park, Sutro Baths & even tried on multiple occasions to gain access to the abandoned hospital.

And then when October brought a beautiful Sunday afternoon along, my girlfriend and I decided to savor it. She had been to Land's End before & wouldn't let another day pass without me experiencing it with her.

It was AMAZING! A little too crowded with tourists on the weekend, but some of the best views in San Francisco I have seen as of yet. There are tons of spots to wander off the main path & find solace of your own. 

After being led to this spot, I've realized how much I still love living in the Richmond...just a few moments away from yet another beautiful attraction created by the dude upstairs.

I will definitely be back here, hopefully on a day when I am the only one wandering these beautiful paths.

---

For more information about the abandoned hospital (PHSH):
http://www.flickr.com/photos/loupiote/sets/433042/
author: matt m.

description:
I used to live right here (yes I've lived in almost every neighborhood in the CIty).  I was stupid then.  I didn't realize how good I had it.  Every morning at sunrise I would take my coffee and walk to that deck and enjoy the sunrise over the Golden Gate before heading out to work.  Silence except for the waves and the birds.  

It is magical out here.  A little taste of the Elysium Fields.  When I go to Heaven, this had better be a part of it or I'm outta there.
author: Robyn C.

description: Fantastic hiking trails within SF city limits...a 9 mile stretch from Ft Funston to the GG Bridge that offers amazing views of the Pacific Ocean and (on a clear day) the most beautiful bridge in the world.  Willie loved roaming the trails with us off leash (he's quite the hiker) but be technically this is a leash only area.  Shhh, don't tell the man, I can't afford a ticket.
author: phil h.

description:
Beautiful, spectacular views of the west side of the Golden Gate, the headlands to the north, and the Pacific ocean with all the craggy drama you expect of the northern California coast below you.  The coast trail, which winds around where a streetcar used to go ages and ages ago is a must, and the offshoots down to the beaches are absolutely worth it.
On a clear day, you can see the Farallon Islands 20 some miles offshore.

The Legion of Honor is also here, and is another of San Francisco's spectacular museums absolutely worth a visit.

The park is also adjacent to the Sutro Baths, which is another cool, historic spot to visit (and makes for some amazing photographic opportunities if the weather is clear and you're there at sundown).
author: Don H.

description:
If Oompa Loompas invaded the planet..and I had one day left on Earth I would spend it at Lands End. Seriously, this is my favorite place in SF. You have the gorgeous look of the GG Bridge and Marin on one side and the look out of the Pacific on the other. 

The trail is nice. I run through it all the time and it's the best part of the run. It's a short hike through the place but you'll be staring at the most gorgeous views you'll stop every 5 minutes to enjoy it. The views are so amazing that you'll often see photographers taking photos during the day. It's that amazing. 

One side of the trail ends where you can loop around to the Legion of Honor. The other side ends near Ocean Beach/Sutro Bath so you can easily make a day here.

They also just completed renovating one side of the trails. They did some repaving and put out more lookout points. I guess when you thought it couldn't get any better it does.
author: Dan T.

description:
Probably one of the most hauntingly beautiful hiking trails in the Bay Area.  Start by wandering through the neatly trimmed (but car-dominated) streets of the Sea-Cliff neighbourhood near China Beach.  Then walk along the trail atop the San Francisco Headlands and enjoy the majestic views of the cliffs, the ocean bluffs and the Golden Gate Bridge.

What makes it all the more amazing is that it's actually right in the city, and fairly accessible with the 38 bus.  I really hope they don't ruin it with all the new parking lots and trail expansion that they are working on right now.
author: Haywood H.

description:
I used to think Lands End was an outdoorsy clothing brand.  Now I know that it is an outdoorsy clothing brand AND a beautiful park.  A lot of people like to go up to Sausalito for a nice view of the GG bridge.  I too was one of these people until I gave Lands End a try.  I biked up here one sunny afternoon and as I hiked through the trails there was a clearing with one of the best views of the bridge I've seen.  It's also relatively uncrowded which is rare for an SF park on a sunny day.  That's fine.  Stay in Golden Gate Park.  Lands End is MINE. 

P.S. There are mountain biking trails here but watch out because some trails have biking forbidden and you can get a ticket.
author: William S.

description:
I'm not going to say something ridiculous like, "The ocean is totally overrated," but if I were to pick an ocean trail or a forest trail, I'd pick the forest one because it's calmer and less windy. Which is why the Lands End Park/Trail is "only" my second favorite hike in the Bay Area. (First place goes to the Strawberry Canyon-Claremont Canyon trails near Berkeley)

That's not to say Lands End isn't a great place to unwind. Regardless of how bad the last week might have been, a combo of sitting and watching the ocean and exploring the many side paths of the Sutro Baths area/Coastal Trail is an excellent way to prepare for a new week.

My favorite part of the trail is Mile Rock Beach (also called Lands End Beach). It's about 0.75-1 mile from the trail head, and down a very long flight of stairs. Three reasons why I like it so much:

1. It's very secluded. It's no surprise that it's a nudist hangout (supposedly -- it's so secluded that there were no nudists during any of my hikes).

2. The Land's End Labyrinth, which other Yelpers have already mentioned. The steps down to the beach forks in the middle -- to the the left is more steps, and to the right is a dirt path. Take the right path and you'll end up at a cliff located above another path. From there, you can look down at the "labyrinth" -- it's more like a gauntlet, since there's no branching paths once you enter it.

If you Google for information about the labyrinth, you'll find that it's made by one artist guy who's also done other labyrinths around the Bay Area. That kind of takes away from the mystery of it all, but the location (atop a semi-secret cliff) and the surrounding view makes up for it.

The cliff above the labyrinth is also a great place to sit down and take in the view of the bay. Be warned, though, it'll probably be occupied by other couples.

3. All the little things that you can discover: Meticulously-balanced rock towers that people have built among the rock piles on the beach. The seagulls that literally "float" up right beside you, catching the strong winds near the cliffs.

My advice for fellow hikers: Don't leave the trail at the Legion of Honor fork. It's very disenchanting to leave an oceanside trail and end up in a lame golf course.

Accessible by Public Transit: Several bus routes including Muni #38 drops you off near the western trailhead.
author: Ryo M.

description:
Great views, good hiking, lots of different paths.  This is my second favorite park in SF (GG Park is numba one).  This park is especially nice in the early early mornings when there's nobody on the trails, and it's not too hot or dusty.  The views of the mouth of the bay are great from here, and you can catch good views of the GG Bridge, Baker Beach, China Beach, and all kinds of other nifty things.  

Favorite thing to do here is hike the trail from the Richmond side and go over to the Cliff to grab a light bite or drink, then hike it on back, usually by a different route.
author: Patrick B.

description: I had been wanting to check out the Sutro Baths for years and when we finally took the time to do so, we also stumbled upon the Coastal Trail and followed it to Lands End Park.  I was amazed at the stunning beauty and sense of remote locale in the midst of San Francisco.  Walking the entire trail we probably came across five people or so and when we reached the amazing Lands End Park we sat on the bench staring out at the Golden Gate entirely alone for a good half hour.  Peace and tranquility just minutes from the center of a major city....what a treat!
author: Lindsay S.

description:
Mike says living in the Richmond is like living on a boat or a dock.  When he was here he would run out to Land's End, cruising the single track dirt path all the way to Great Highway, and turn around at the bottom of the hill just down from the Cliff House.  

On his way back the wind would practically push him up the hill - he said he barely had to use his legs.  

Land's end is raw and beautiful.  It is my church.  Just when the city has completely choked my will to live I am saved by the serenity, calmed by the sounds of the mighty pacific meeting the jagged shores below, moved by the vision of the headlands stretching out to form point reyes, far in the distance.  

This is no ordinary place.  This is a place where dead souls come to life.  

I saw Mike in Santa Cruz last week.  We talked about Land's end.  He is still amazed by the fact that the wind carried him up the hill past the Cliff house, and put him back on the trail.  I guess when you're in tune, good things happen.  

Come here for the views.  Stay for the afterlife.
author: chris o.

description:
City life can be tough.  Do you want a place that can transport you away from all of that noisy concrete stress?  If you answered yes, this is your place.  If you answered no you are a schmuck and you should move to NYC so you can be miserable all the time.

Not to pick sides or anything, but I believe that we all need a break from the city every once in a while.  Lands End park is the perfect break for the SF city dweller.  Drive out to the Seacliff area, walk about five minutes, and all of a sudden you are walking on a dirt trail situated 500 feet above the Pacific Ocean.  All around you are trees, hills, rocks, and ocean....seriously  you have to make an effort to get a glimpse of the city.  

Not only does the park offer spectacular views, it allows you to escape into the world famous Nor-Cal beach scene, complete with sheer cliffs, rocky beach access, and breathtaking panoramas, all conveniently confined in the north west part of the city.

Take the time to read the historical signs and check out the shipwreck remnants....places like this are what make San Francisco such a unique and memorable city.
author: Brian H.

description:
Holy freaking crap.

I can't believe that I have lived in SF all this time (ok, just one year) and never went out to Lands End.  I kept telling myself I would take my parents there the next time they came down, but if I had known how amazing it is out here, I wouldn't have dreamed of putting it off so long.

I've discovered lots of places in SF where it hardly feels like you're in a city (Mt Davidson, Stern Grove, Sutro Forest, to name a few) but this trumps them all.  The cliffs and cypress trees out here make you feel like you're in Monterey.  And the coastal trail here is LONG.  I think it's nearly 3 miles from the Cliff House to the 32nd Ave trailhead.  I must come back here, repeatedly.  The people who live close enough to jog here every day are some seriously lucky folks.

Seriously, if you want to impress people with the natural beauty within the city, forget the Presidio or Golden Gate Park, start right here at Lands End.
author: Wes M.

description:
One of my favorite places to show people from out of town. Amazing pacific views. On a clear day you can see the farallon islands. And views of the GG bridge second only to certain vantage points in the marin headlands. There is also this funky rock art at the end of one of the coastal trails - very san francisco!

UPDATE
=======
The coastal trails are closed right now for some sort of renovation.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Lands End is quite wonderful and I continue to appreciate it,well even though I fell and hurt myself previously(I have recovered and returned).

Simply wonderful and I have told other people I know to come check it out that like the outdoors.
author: Dani D.

description:
Paradise found within the city limits.

Wander off the beaten path for breathtaking views of the North Bay, the Golden Gate Bridge, large barges coming in and out of the bay, and die-hard surfers. Venture far west and find the rocky little beach where you'll get a front-seat sunset view. A peaceful oasis in the city. One of my favorite local spots for trail running - there's a nice set of stairs for when I'm feeling extra energetic.
author: Sara C.

description: Point Lobos is so beautiful. I came here to paint with a group of friends a few months ago and it was perfect (a little chilly, but there wasn't any fog)! The park rangers are really nice and the trails were great
author: Jasmine T.

description: My in-laws took us here. We parked in a parking lot and took about a 15 minute hike down to the beach. Make sure to wear good shoes and watch your kids because it gets narrow and steep and the walk back up can be a bit tiring. The trail is pretty and the view from the beach at the bottom of the hill is breathtaking. It is windy and cold so good idea to wear a sweatshirt or light jacket. We spent 6 days in San Francisco with native's as our guide. By far, this was the most beautiful and serene part of our trip. I wish it had been warm enough to eat at the Park Chalet but, it was just too cold that day. What a peaceful place. This is the place that makes me long to go back to San Francisco.
author: Ellie S.
